Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Leveraging Simultaneous Access to Multiple Frequency Bands in Multihop Wireless Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Due to the culmination of the recent reapportionment of FCC frequency bands and the acceleration of wireless device complexity, simultaneous access to multiple diverse wireless frequency bands is becoming more of a reality. Naturally, the question arises: How can simultaneous access to a wide range of frequency bands with distinct propagation and communication capabilities improve current wireless network performance? In this CAREER research, a foundation is laid for exploiting multiple frequency bands for multihop wireless networks from per-link to network-wide decisions. To do so, this project uses experimental design, measurement analysis, analytical modeling, and embedded programming on an array of devices and testbeds from mobile phones globally reachable via application downloads to in-lab and in-the-field wireless infrastructures.

There are three key innovations to the work: 1) An experimental characterization for multiple frequency band propagation characteristics by leveraging mobile phone measurements and in-field trials on a number of frequency bands, 2) A network planning framework for scalable, multiband architectures that uses empirical and analytical models for capacity prediction of heterogeneous topological formations across a diverse set of frequency bands, and 3) Protocols that coordinate and adapt link parameters across multiple wireless frequency bands, guided by real-time measurements of channel variability, an understanding of environmental context, and on-line training based on historical performance. As a result of work, multihop wireless network researchers, developers, and infrastructure providers can leverage the framework to exploit multiple frequency bands in a broad class of network protocols, topologies, and environments via available experimental data, analytical model development, and protocol design.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of the project was to leverage knowledge of propagation differences (in terms of large-scale fading) and channel variability (in terms of small-scale fading and spectral activity) in diverse frequency bands to improve link adaptation and multihop network planning. In particular, an understanding of small-scale fading and channel activity was achieved via local measurement and analysis in the lab and in the field using a combination of custom hardware or off-the-shelf hardware and predominantly used for adapting wireless links across modulation orders, coding levels, beamforming weights, or frequency bands. Moreover, an understanding of large-scale fading was achieved via Android-based crowdsourcing of WiFi and cellular networks and predominantly used for increasing the total served user demand of a multihop wireless network. Over the course of the project, there have been a number of thrusts that all work towards understanding the propagation and channel fluctuations of various frequency bands and technologies for the purpose of improved link and network adaptation. In particular, the project included the following three main thrusts.

(1) Spectral and propagation measurements were performed for many diverse frequencies ranging from 400 MHz to 5.8 GHz over the Dallas-Fort Worth area and the Taos area (a second SMU campus) with mobile and handheld spectrum analyzers with and without users inducing losses on the reception of these frequency bands. These measurements have been used for multi-band adaptation of a single frequency-flexible link, to build multihop frequency-diverse (e.g., white space, WiFi, cellular) networks, or inform license assisted and other forms of dynamic access. The project showed an order of magnitude savings when jointly using these frequency bands over multihop topologies and significant power savings.

(2) Signal strength measurements across WiFi and cellular networks were crowdsourced from mobile phone and wireless-enabled devices via an Android application, WiEye, to collect 250 million data points. These measurements have either been used to compare against more advanced drive testing equipment (e.g., a channel scanner) to understand how well the mobile phones can predict propagation and fading or with geographical data (e.g., LiDAR) to understand the role of each feature such as tree and building heights and densities on the propagation effects. The project also showed that the mobile phones are comparable to advanced equipment in inferred radio propagation, within 0.1 of the calculated path loss exponent by the more advanced equipment across downtown, single-family, and multi-family residential areas.

(3) Drone-based communication systems were built and used in in-field experimentation to understand air-to-ground and ground-to-air propagation and fading across multiple frequency bands, and experimentally evaluating various beamforming approaches such as with implicit and explicit feedback. Three key issues for deploying drone-based beamforming systems were addressed: channel reciprocity, feedback overhead, and update rate for channel estimation. In addressing these issues, it was found that explicit feedback approaches were better at tracking mobile beamforming systems and that amplitude was more conducive to a channel reciprocity assumption than phase in air-to-ground channels.

The PI created a course called Introduction to Drone Communications on the SMU-in-Taos campus and has been using this course to train student researchers and expose non-researchers to concepts addressed in the project. The PI founded a STEM Club at a local elementary school and has exposed K-2 students to many aspects related to the project including unmanned aerial vehicles and wireless communications and networking. Lastly, the PI was awarded the Golden Mustang Teaching Award, an award that is given to one tenure-track Assistant Professor each year at SMU.
